original_data.question: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of left knee pain as well as stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes. The pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs. There is no history of trauma. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Her mother died of metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago, at the age of 65 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin. Over the past 2 months, she has been taking over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31.8 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line; there is crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension. Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee?

options.A: Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray
options.B: Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray
options.C: Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound

model_response:
The most likely finding on imaging of the left knee is osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray. This patient has osteoarthritis of the knee. The history of left knee pain for 3 months, worse with standing and climbing stairs, and tenderness on examination over the anteromedial joint line are consistent with this diagnosis. The patient's age, obesity, and family history of breast cancer are not risk factors for osteoarthritis. The normal serum uric acid concentration and erythrocyte sedimentation rate exclude the diagnoses of gout and an inflammatory arthritis, respectively. Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis. It most often affects the knees, hips, cervical and lumbosacral spine, and first metatarsal phalangeal joints. Radiographically, osteoarthritis is characterized by the loss of joint cailage, with accompanying sclerosis of the underlying bone. Large osteophytes may be present at the joint margins. The pannus seen in rheumatoid arthritis is not present.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
A sensation of tightness in a toe joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. []
Used to indicate that an event is to commence following the end of sleeping.
A unit measure of time equal to 60 seconds.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
The act of assuming or maintaining an erect upright position.
A defined quantity of manufactured material or product produced in a single manufacturing process or series of process steps so that it reasonably is expected to be homogeneous.
Record and study of past events.
Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
A condition with abnormally high levels of CHOLESTEROL in the blood. It is defined as a cholesterol value exceeding the 95th percentile for the population.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Female parents, human or animal.
Irreversible cessation of all bodily functions, manifested by absence of spontaneous breathing and total loss of cardiovascular and cerebral functions.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Visible gaseous suspension of carbon and other particulate matter emitted from burning substances.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

A synthetic lipid-lowering agent. Atorvastatin competitively inhibits hepatic hydroxymethyl-glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase, the enzyme which catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a key step in cholesterol synthesis. Atorvastatin also increases the number of LDL receptors on hepatic cell surfaces to enhance uptake and catabolism of LDL and reduces LDL production and the number of LDL particles. This agent lowers plasma cholesterol and lipoprotein levels and modulates immune responses by suppressing MHC II (major histocompatibility complex II) on interferon gamma-stimulated, antigen-presenting cells such as human vascular endothelial cells. (NCI04)
A salicylamide derivative that is a non-cardioselective blocker of BETA-ADRENERGIC RECEPTORS and ALPHA-1 ADRENERGIC RECEPTORS.

The prototypical analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain. It has anti-inflammatory and antipyretic properties and acts as an inhibitor of cyclooxygenase which results in the inhibition of the biosynthesis of prostaglandins. Aspirin also inhibits platelet aggregation and is used in the prevention of arterial and venous thrombosis. (From Martindale, The Extra Pharmacopoeia, 30th ed, p5)
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent with analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory properties
Pain in the joint.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A dull achy pain.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
Denoting the front portion of the body towards the median plane.
Air trapped in the subcutaneous space. It can be palpated or heard as a crackling or grating sensation under the skin.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Tests for iliosacral or sacroiliac somatic dysfunction.
To increase in length or duration.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of uric acid present in a sample of serum.
Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing HEMOGLOBIN whose function is to transport OXYGEN.
The act or process of settling particles by mechanical means from a state of suspension in air or water.
The act of ascertaining or fixing the value or worth of something.
Clinical manifestations that can be either objective when observed by a physician, or subjective when perceived by the patient.

Any visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation. It includes measuring physiologic and metabolic responses to physical and chemical stimuli, as well as ultramicroscopy.
